div.sent: The holy places are the most sacred places for all people.
Every religion has its own holy places.
The Buddhists also have many holy places.
These places are the most sacred places for them.
These holy places are divided into two parts, namely, the most holy lands and the sacred places.
Lumbini The birth place of Siddhartha.
Buddha GayaThe holy place for attaining Buddhahood.
Sarnath Famous for delivering first sermon The Dhammacakka Pavattana.
Kusinagar The place of Mahaparinibbana, the Great Passing away of the Buddha.
Among the holy places there are Sravasti, Rajagriha, Vaisali and Sankasya.
Many remembrances of the Buddha's life are implicated in these four holy places.
So these places are very sacred to the Buddhists.
These eight conspicuous places are called Attamahathana (eight famous places) unitedly.
Kapilavastu, Sanchi, Ajanta, Taxila; Nalanda, Paharpur, Mahasthangar, Maynamati etc.
These places are world famous for wonderful evidences of architecture, sculptor and artistical works.
Among them Taxila and Nalanda have been considered as the best seat of learning in Asia.
Sanchi, Ajanta, Maynamati, Paharpur, Mahasthangar are famous for architecture and artistic works.
Kapilavastu is renowned for about 29 years memorable life of Gautama.
These places are renowned for the religious inspiration and as the historical places too.
In ancient time, stupas (mounds), buildings and vihara (monasteries) were constructed in these places.
Many memories of the Buddha's life are involved with these eight large holy places.
Again, among the other places, many memories of the Buddha's life are involved with Kapilavastu and Nalanda.
We are very lucky that Maynamati, Mahasthangar and Paharpur are situated in Bangladesh.
We can visit these places easily.
It is a virtuous deed to wander about visiting places of pilgrimage.
We ought to obey religion and it is also our sacred duty to visit pilgrimage.
By visiting holy places mind becomes pure and restless mind becomes calm.
The broadness of mind increases.
People from different countries of home and abroad use to visit these holy places.
As a result brotherliness among the people of these.
There are good results of visiting holy places too.
By this one alleviates misery, acquires religious merits and attains good way in the next world.
By visiting historical places knowledge increases.
One can see glorious deed of past and grows curiosity to know more.
So everybody should go to visit the holy places according to ability.
We need to expand our knowledge by visiting the historical places.
Now we shall explain about some of the sacred places and historical places.
Kapilavastu is situated in Nepal at the foot of the Himalayas.
Kaiplavastu was the capital of Siddhartha's father, the king Suddhodana of the Sakya clan.
It is now named Padariva.
Kapilavastu stands on the bank of the river Rohini.
It is said that once in the past, there, a saint Kapil by name, built a shelter by cutting jungle.
From that time this was named Kapilavastu.
Kapilavastu was a small kingdom under the Kosala empire.
Suddhodana, the king of Kapilavastu, was the king of Sakya race.
Prince Siddhartha was the son of king Suddhodana.
Kapilavastu is famous for various reasons.
Siddhartha was born in the Lumbini garden, not far from Kapilavastu.
From his birth to the day of renunciation of the world Siddhartha passed his long life in the city of Kapilavastu.
So there lies many memories of His life in this city.
Once in his boyhood watching ploughing festival Siddhartha was found absorbed in deep meditation.
Devadatta once wounded a swan by his arrow.
Siddhartha cured the wounded-swan and made it to fly in the sky.
The prince Siddhartha got marry Yasodhara in the palace of Kapilavastu city.
Before renunciation of worldly life Siddhartha travelled around the city and He saw four scenes.
Three of them were sorrowful and the other was an ascetic.
Why are there so sufferings in the world?
What is the way to attain emancipation?
In quest of the solutions of the above questions He left home on the birth-day of His son Rahula.
After He had received Buddhahood He came to Kapilavastu with His disciples on an invitation from king Suddhodana.
He took his shelter in Negrodhkunja.
He delivered His religious sermons there.
After hearing this religious topics from Him, His father, step-mother, wife and many of the Sakyas initiated themselves into Buddhist religion.
He initiated His son Rahula into Buddhist religion-here, too.
Kapilavastu has thus become so significant in the history of Buddhism.
Rajagriha is situated to the south-east of Patna district of Bihar in-India.
At present the name of Rajagriha is Rajgir.
This Rajagriha is a very old city which is situated in the valley surrounded by the five hills.
Many events and incidents of Gautarna Buddha's life have taken place in this old city.
So Rajagriha is a holy land for the Buddhist community.
During the period of the Buddha, Bimbisara was the king of Magadha.
Rajagriha was the capital of his kingdom.
King Bimbisara was Buddha's contemporary and a great devotee to Him.
Many memories of the Buddha's life are involved with Rajagriha.
After leaving the palace Siddhartha at first received religious instruction from Arar Kalam and Rudraka in Rajagriha.
After attaining Buddhahood (Enlightenment), He started preaching His religion from Rajagriha.
Then He passed here many years and observed many Varsavasa here.
King Bimbisara gifted Venuvana for living the disciples of the Buddha.
Venuvana Vihara was one of the dearest dwelling-shelter of the Buddha.
In Venuvana He initiated into His religion Sariputta and Moggallayana.
There is a warm-stream named Tapoda near Venuvana.
The pilgrims take their hathe here.
They believe that gout and skin diseases etc. are recovered by taking bathe here.
There is a cave named Pipphali over this stream.
Mahakassapa used to live in the cave.
The Buddha came here several times.
Saptaparni Guha (cave) is to the west of Pipphali cave.
The first Buddhist Conference took place here under the patronage of king Ajatasatru.
Ajatasatru, imprisoned his father king Bimbisara and kept him under custody in Rajagriha.
King Bimbisara died in the prison.
Devadatta plotted with Ajatasatru to kill Buddha in Rajagriha. .
There is the Mango-grove of the Royal physician Jivaka in Rajagriha.
Jivaka was a great devotee to the Buddha and was also his physician.
Jivaka bestowed his mango-orchard to the Buddha and His disciples.
The Buddha also stayed in some other places of Rajagriha.
The name of the places are Gridhrakuta hill, Gautama Negrodharama, Choraprapat, Kalosila, Sarpasoundik Guha, Venuvana, Madrakukkhi etc.
Buddha delivered his religious sermons to his followers several times in these places.
The city-plan of Rajagriha was very beautiful.
The city was surrounded by two high walls.
There were 96 gates in these wall of which 32 were big and 64 were small.
One can go to Rajagriha changing the Rail at Bakhtiarpur station from Calcutta and Patna.
One can go to this holy place from Calcutta by road too.
Sravasti stands on the bank of the river Achiravati in the district of Gonda under the Northern province of India.
Some people think that everything was available here for which it was named Sabastha or Savastha.
On the contrary some others think that there lived a saint named Sabastha, So Sravasti was named after his name.
The present-name of Sravasti is Sahet-Mahet.
It is about 21 kilometre away from Balarampur Station.
One can go by bus from Balarampur station too.
During the period of the Buddha Sravasti was a big village in North Province.
It was the capital and a commercial area of Kosala king Prasenjit.
There are so many memories of the Buddha's life at Sravasti.
So Sravasti is one of the chief holy places of the Buddhists.
There were three famous monasteries in Sravasti, these are Jetavana, Purbaram and Rajakaram.
Amonb them Jetavana Vihara was very beautiful.
The rich merchant (Shresthi) Sudatta of.
Sravasti gifted this vihara to the Buddha.
He was very dear lay disciple of the Buddha.
He liked and selected grove for buildina a monastery for the Buddha and His disciples.
This was the pleasure- garden of prince Jeta.
The prince demanded very high price when the merchant Sudatta had wanted to purchase the grove.
He said that he would sell the land if the merchant could cover the entire land with the gold-coins as its price.
The merchant Sudatta covered the land with gold-coins.
Then he built there a large monastery.
There were bed-rooms, prayer-hall; cave, store-room, meditation-room, space for circumambulation, tank, bath-room and many other necessary provisions for the monks.
There were some colleges in Jetavana Vihara.
Among them the name of Kosamba kuti and Mahagandha kuti are mentionable.
The Buddha observed 19 Varsavasa in Jetavana.
Mahaupasika Visakha conferred to Buddha a Mahavihara named Purbaram.
Visakha was a beautiful daughter of a rich merchant of Saket.
Later the rich merchant of Sravasti named Migar made his daughter-in-law.
Visakha was devotee of the Buddha.
She was called Migar-mata.
So the Purbaram Vihara is known as Migar-mata palace too.
The monastery was two-storied.
The Buddha stayed in this monastery for six Varsa.
The third monastery of Jetavana is Rajakaram.
King Prasenjit of Kosala built this monastery.
The king Prasenjit also built an inn here at the request of the queen.
It was named Mallikaram.
Anjanavan (forest) was adjacent to Sravasti.
Gavampati, a disciple of the Buddha, lived here.
Theri Sujata attained Arahatta here, after listening to the preaching of the Buddha.
Utpalabanna; Aggasavika of the Buddha also lived in Sravasti.
The wrecked portions of old Sravasti are found in the place named Mahet and Sahet at present.
The destroyed portion of Jetavana vihara covered about 32 acres at Mahet.
The ruined portions of original Sravasti city are spread out about four hundred acres area at Sahet.
These two places are only one kilometre distance from each other.
Once upon a time Nalanda was the greatest seat of learning in India.
It is situated in Patna district at present Bihar of India.
It is about 10 kilometre away from Rajagriha.
In the outskirts of Rajagriha, Nalanda was then a prosperous village.
From the source of Pali Text it is known that Gautama Buddha came several times to Nalanda and took rest at Pavarika Mango grove.
He praised of Nalanda.
It is said that the emperor Asoka laid the foundation stone of Nalanda Mahavihara.
After the death of emperor Asoka, Nalanda Mahavihara was developed with the donation of many kings and rich persons.
The fame of Nalanda spread during the reign of Pala kings.
The Pala rulers gifted land for Nalanda Vihara.
They built big monasteries and libraries.
Thus Nalanda Mahavihara turned into famous University in the fifteenth century.
Gradually the fame of Nalanda spread all around.
Nalanda University is surrounded by high walls.
The rooms of the university are high.
The top of each room is found.
A renowned Chinese traveller Yit-Singh said, There, were eight hall-rooms and three hundred rooms in Nalanda University.
Beyond this there were dwelling rooms of students.
Two students were accommodated in each room.
There were a bedstand and a table for them in each room.
These were stone-made.
After digging of archaeology plenty of artistical works were found.
Beyond this, there were found plates, cups, pots etc. used by monks and students.
These are preserved in the museum of Nalanda.
It is said, once upon a time there lived 10,000 people in the Nalanda University.
Among them 1500 people were professors and 8000 students.
Except bed-time, the work of teaching continued from morning till evening, The library was very Prosperous.
Many renowned scholars were the students of this university.
Not only from different parts of India, the learners used to come from abroad to study in Nalanda.
Huen Tsang was a residential student of Nalanda University for five years.
Yit-Singh was a learner for about ten years.
Bhikkhu Shilabhadra was then the principal of Nalanda University.
Great philosopher Nagarjun was also a student of this University.
Later he was appointed the Principal of the Nalanda University.
The Buddhist Philosopher and Logician Ding Nag also stayed in Nalanda for many days.
Nalanda University was the main centre of practising Buddhist Philosophy.
Beyond this, medical science, logic, phonology, chemistry and another subjects were also taught there.
After completing the education, the learners were given title on the basis of merit.
In a special festival the local king gave certificates Kulapati and Pandita to the meritorious students.
The then Nalanda University is no more today.
Several times it was attacked and destroyed by the enemy.
At present the Bihar Government set up an education centre named New Nalanda Mahavihara for studying Buddhist Religious Education.
In many parts of Bangladesh, there were found the instances of Buddhists architectures, after digging of archaeology.
Maynamati of Comilla district is one of them.
Maynamati is about eight kilometre away from Comilla town.
Once upon a time Maynamati was the centre of practising of Buddhist Philosophy in the East India.
In the eighth century this region was under the kings of Deva dynasty.
Then the name of Maynamati was Pattikera.
During the period of the Deva kings there developed ancient Buddhist institutions.
At that time the kings of Chandra dynasty reigned in this region.
All of them were followers of Buddhism.
The Buddhists organizations flourished more with their patronization.
There are Buddhists villages near Maynamati.
It is presumed that the name of Pattikera was named Maynamati after the name of the queen of king Manik Chandra of the Chandra dynasty.
This was the main city of the Chandra race.
This city was situated on the Lalmai hill.
Perhaps the, soil of hill was red, so it was called Lalmai hill.
Gradually the city was turned down under the earth for several reasons.
After digging of archaeology, so many old architectural arts were discovered.
Among these Salvan Vihara, palace of king Andha, Rupban Mura, palace of Bhoj raja.
Kutilmura, Chandimura etc. are main.
It is supposed that Salvan Vihara was made during the period of the Deva dynasty.
Later this Mahavihara had been reconstructed and extended several times.
The monastery was rebuilt four times on the upper level.
The peculiarity of Salvan Vihara is, it is equal in length and breadth.
The main shrine was in centre.
There are 11.5 rooms surrounding the central Shrine.
All of the rooms are equal.
The monks stayed, meditated and learnt their lessons there.
There is a courtyard and a varanda in front of the monastery.
There were four vistior-rooms in four corners.
There was only one gate in the monastery.
The name of Kutilmura is next to Salvan Vihara.
Kutilmura is situated about five kilometre north to the Salvan Vihara.
There are found the ruins of three stupas.
It is supposed that the three stupas were made as the symbols of Tiratana Buddha, Dhamma and Sangha.
A temple has been found at Charpatra Mura in the north-west of Kutilmura.
The ruins of the palace of king Ananda has been found in another place, too.
There are monastery and the images of the Buddha and Padmapani of Bodhisattva.
An image of the Buddha has been found at Rupbanmura.
Bodhisattva Manjusree and Padmapani Buddha have been found at Chandimura.
Lately there has been discovered a large image of the Buddha.
There were found Arabian coins too.
These things are kept in the museum.
One can go easily to Maynamati as it is very near to the Comilla Railway station.
